text: We'll hear argument next in Case 08-1569, United States v. O'Brien.

Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: Section 924(c)(1) starts by defining a single crime of using or carrying a firearm during and in relation to a crime of violence or a drug trafficking crime.
Well wait.
--Well, no, and, of course--
I mean, (A) says,
--Well, I agree with you that the phrase (A) as well.

So does -- so does the language of (A)(ii) and (A)(iii), which is the same language: "if the firearm is brandished"; "if the firearm is discharged" -- they all apply to a conviction for carrying the firearm.
--Well, I agree.
So that makes (A) the same as (B).
--Well, I certainly don't claim that they -- that the elements in the principal paragraph of (A) are.
No, but you're forgetting the words of this subsection.
--Well--
--the subsection would be (B) itself.
--Well, I agree it doesn't use "subparagraph".
But still and all, if -- if Congress were being precise and if the statute is to be read the way you suggest, the introduction to capital (B) should have been
--That -- that I think would be so precise that we wouldn't be here discussing it today.
Yes.
--which is not then to say that this subsection -- that everything in this subsection is an element.
I guess I agree with you that if (B) is -- if (B) is an element, (C) would be an element, too.
Well, that certainly would be the inference.

What is this to do -- I mean, the obvious question, to me, is -- since I wrote the -- I think I wrote the opinion in Castillo -- is we looked at the language of the statute, very similar to this, and we said: Machinegun means a separate crime.
--Well, I think there are -- there are several specific changes that Congress made.
Right.
And then the new statute is in the appendix to the government's opening brief at 1a and 2a, so you can look at them side by side.
Isn't the old one in your brief, too, in your--
It is.
--It's 3a of the government's brief.
It is, although, of course, you have to turn the page, and I--
All right.
--Perhaps it's helpful to look at them next to each other, because the differences are quite stark--
All right.
--when you do that.
But it didn't.
--So a few answers there.

Well, except that with -- with (C), you -- you could say that traditionally recidivism has been a sentencing factor, and you cannot say with respect to (B) that whether it's a short-barreled rifle or a machinegun has traditionally been a sentencing factor.

--Well, I disagree with that, Justice Scalia, because the tradition, as I understand it, is relevant because it might indicate what Congress was thinking or what suppositions it had in mind when it passed a statute.
Let's -- let's talk about the guidelines.
Well, the guidelines -- as before and as now for this offense, the guidelines level is the minimum.
The guidelines -- do you think that if under the guidelines the sentence was 30 years because of a machinegun, do you think that that would be upheld?
I'm sorry.
Do you think it would be upheld as a reasonable sentence under our Booker/Fanfan theory of -- of how the guidelines are to be applied?
--A reasonable -- well, certainly courts have, since Booker, imposed even up to a life sentence for offenses that did not otherwise trigger the elevated minimums.
Where -- where is the life sentence maximum, by the way?
--The -- the maximum is not textually in the statute, but all courts that have looked at this have understood that.
Where -- where do you get the life maximum?
--Well, it is certainly the case, if we simply take (a)(1)--
And if it mentions nothing about life, then these are not mandatory minimums.
--I absolutely disagree.
Is the life part of the--
Or not less than.
--what the substantive crime was?
Well, I wouldn't describe it as an add-on.
Well, then -- then you wouldn't be relying on what might be a life sentence for the underlying crime.
--I -- oh, I'm sorry.
Yes, but where do you get the maximum?
--Well, they are minimums because they say 5 years> ["].
But where is -- where is the maximum?
--The -- well, because there is no stated maximum, the -- the assumption then must be that a sentence higher than 5 years is appropriate.

Is there a Sixth Amendment problem with reading a statute this way, with -- with reading a statute to provide for an unlimited maximum when Congress hasn't specified it, and now you're going to have the judge find the minimum and the maximum?
--Well, I don't -- I disagree that the judge is finding the maximum.
I don't find that implied at all.
--Well, the trouble, Justice Scalia, is then that I don't otherwise know what the maximum would be.
That's right.
The maximum--
--That's her question.
But isn't there a Sixth Amendment problem with not knowing what you are exposed to?
I think what you are exposed to, as I read the statute, (c)(1)(A) does not impose a new sentence at all.
--Well, I don't think it would make sense to treat them, as you are describing them, as add-ons.
I'll amend what I said.
--Well, I -- I think it would be helpful then to compare this to the -- the language of the prior statute, which describes exactly what you are describing.
I got it.
Which is -- which is that whoever during or in relation, et cetera, et cetera, uses or carries a firearm--
Can you give us the page?
--I'm sorry, this is at 11a of the petition appendix.
It's also on 3a of the government's brief.
Or 3a of the -- of the government's -- the government's brief.
Right.
--particular determinate sentences.
Right.
If Congress had wanted to continue that approach, I assume it would have kept that language.
It says (c)(1)(A):
--That -- I understand that language, the in -- the "in addition to" language, to have -- to have been to make clear that this is a separate offense.
Yes.

And that then it is a separate -- then from there it is a question what is the appropriate sentence for a conviction on the offense described in 924(c)(1), which is to say, well, it's a term of imprisonment of not less than 5 years, which holds open--
In addition to the term that's -- that exists for the substantive offense.
--I -- I agree.

To make your life a little more complicated and difficult, though perhaps it makes it easier, we reach the questions that Justice Scalia was raising, I think, and they are important only if you win, only if we say that it is a sentencing factor.

--Well, to answer -- well, first of all, there certainly has not been in -- in the briefing or argument here, any opportunity for this Court to consider what it would need to consider to overrule McMillan.
Well, I think basically Apprendi did significantly change McMillan, but that's--

--Well, and that's -- and that would be my -- my second point, is that -- is that since -- I think it has been become clearer since Harris that the rule in McMillan and the rule in Apprendi coexist quite well and coexist in a principled fashion, and that there is -- and that there is no -- Harris was correct in light of Apprendi, which is -- which is in the following respect.
--Does the government believe that it has sufficiently argued this, or would you suggest on the government's behalf that if it becomes an issue it's set for reargument?
Well, yes, we would certainly want to set it for reargument--
That's the right answer.
--obviously.

Why can't we just say, as Judge Boudin did, they weren't -- this revision was on the books before Castillo was decided, so obviously Congress wasn't trying to adjust the statute in response to Castillo.
--Well, I disagree that it's not all that different.
Isn't a minimum always a maximum?
In -- to the person who would otherwise, in the judge's discretion, qualify for a lower sentence, doesn't it become that person's maximum once you have indiscretion?

--I disagree with that because the principle -- the background -- the basic principle behind Apprendi and our criminal law is that what you can rely on is what Congress has said in the statute or in -- as Booker holds--
What you can rely on in an indeterminate sentencing regime without a minimum is that you've got a statutory maximum, whatever it may be, but a judge's discretion to start from zero.
--I disagree with that, because it is not the only thing the judge can give you.
Counsel -- counsel, I think you had said you had three responses to Justice Ginsburg--
--Yes.
--and only got one out.

Right, and perhaps only half of that one, which is -- which is that in the -- on the question of -- of tradition, Congress apparently exclusively uses sentencing factors when it wants to do nothing more than give some rules to the judge to channel his discretion with minimum sentences.
All right.
Number two is that the -- is that the -- the -- the linguistic change here, the textual change, the fact that subparagraph (D) says
Those are all -- all three of those are -- are pretty subtle ways for Congress to change the view in Castillo.
--Well, I would agree that--
Moving something from the body of the paragraph to a separate section and so on.

--Well, I would -- I would point out -- of course, one has to -- one has to recognize what Congress had before it when it -- when it made the change, which is to say, when it -- when it embarked on these revisions, there was a one-to-one circuit split on the question.
Thank you, counsel.
We have tall lawyers today.
Mr. Fisher.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: I think it's important at the outset to set the context for this case.
How about the short -- what is it, the one that gets 10 years, the short-barreled rifle?
We think, Justice Ginsburg, that if this Court had to construe that statute in a different case, that provision, it would find it's still an element.
Oh, I guess I'm not following the ball here.
I don't understand that to be what the government has said.
Now, they have to because that's what Harris said, brandished--
That's -- yes, that's Harris.
--brandished is a sentencing factor.
That's right.
--Well, that's even worse, then.
So what sub (B) does, as I said, is it creates a greater offense, and so, it's broken out in a way that incorporates the earlier elements up above in the main paragraph by using the phrase: If a
No, their -- their -- their basic argument is look at the statute.
Right.
And you believe there is a background of life sentence?
--I don't think that's necessarily the case, Justice Scalia.
--Well, it either is or isn't.

--has said a couple of times that this is a theoretical maximum sentence, but, surely, if nothing else, the Sentencing Reform Act sets a maximum sentence here if it's not just a straight determinant sentence.
What's the -- I don't want to interrupt your nice organization here.
--Let me answer it--
Other than, this is just--
--If I might say one more--
--other than how awful this is.
--If I might say one more sentence to Justice Breyer, and then I'll answer that.
Please.

Justice Breyer, the other thing I'd point out is that, so therefore, once you make the Bailey fix, you just come -- in the old statute, then you come to the machinegun provision, and you just leave it where it was.
Is that just based on empirical studies or is there guideline support for that?
There is both, Your Honor.
I understand.
--but the guideline sentences as -- as to this statute are pegged exactly to the mandatory minimums.
I'm sorry.
Under the facts that either we prove to the jury or are admitted by the defendant.
--There must be some statutory provision that you -- that you -- that you rely upon.
Oh, certainly, Justice Scalia.
Where does 7 years come from?
Seven years comes from -- comes from the statute, for brandishing, which is what both defendants had admitted that they did.
Yes, but we know that's a sentencing factor.
--But they've admitted it.

How do we find it with this statute, if there's a 10-year minimum/maximum under (A) subdivision (iii) if the firearm is discharged, and it's 10 years; and if it's a short-barreled rifle under (B), it's also an equal amount, of 10 years?
--How do we find substantively unreasonable after Booker?
Unreasonableness, that there was an act of manipulation here, or intent to manipulate.
Well, if you're asking me the question -- I want to be sure I understand and answer the question.
Exactly.
--I don't think you have to look any further -- well, there is two places you can look.
Well, the Court's -- the Court's opinion in Castillo quite carefully noted that it wasn't addressing this statute.
I don't contend that Castillo absolutely decides the case.
The prior statute -- which was 18 U.S.C. 924(c)(1), right?
They -- as you say, they were not in the statute itself.
It's a collateral point: Does the government have to show, or does the -- don't you have to find that the machinegun is operable?
I assume so, but I don't know the specific answer to that, Justice Kennedy.
Thank you, Mr. Fisher.
Thank you.
Is there anything other -- do we have anything other than the statute itself?
Well, there is no legislative history, but there is the fact that the form manual says if you're going to embark on this, here are some ideas for how to do it.
Thank you, counsel.
